question.body: (T/F) Microeconomics concentrates on aggregates such as economic growth and inflation.

choice.body: True
False

question.body: When we have two soft drinks on a hot day and turn down the offer of a free third soft drink because we feel this might be too much and leave us waterlogged, we are

choice.body: thinking irrationally because it is free.
helping alleviate scarcity by leaving something for someone else.
thinking on the margin.
using information to gain an advantage in the market.

question.body: The following figure shows 2006 GDP per capita for selected countries, and the country's corresponding years of life expectancy at birth for both men and women. Russia's per capita GDP is roughly what percent of America's?
In following figure, which country has the highest life expectancy for males/females?

choice.body: France/Germany
United Kingdom/United States
Japan/United Kingdom
Japan/Japan

question.body: The following figure shows the median (middle person) duration of unemployment in weeks for each month for 2002â??2004. Notice that there is a spike in how long people have been unemployed each June. Which of the following is probably the best explanation for these spikes in how long people have been unemployed?

choice.body: Employers do not like to hire people in June because they don't want to have to let new people go on vacation.
The unemployed see the arrival of summer as a chance to surf and do not bother to look for a job.
May and June represent graduation in both high school and college, so the job market becomes crowded and many unemployed individuals can't find work.
Federal law restricts the number of people who can interview for federal jobs in the summer because of budget limitations.

question.body: The following figure shows the relationship between the size of a video file in megabytes and the download time in minutes. What is the slope of the line?

Assume the line (relationship) in the following figure is for your medium-speed DSL line. Now assume you get a high-speed broadband network connection. How does that affect the line in the following figure?

choice.body: No impact.
The line will rotate downward with a smaller slope.
The line will rotate upward with a larger slope.
Broadband is so fast that the line will equal the horizontal axis.

question.body: (T/F) Ceteris paribus means that economists do economics by creating models.

choice.body: True
False

question.body: Macroeconomics covers all EXCEPT which one of the following?

choice.body: the inflation rate
the unemployment rate
productivity rates
sales of NIKE athletic shoes compared to Reeboks

question.body: Models are:

choice.body: useless because they are too simple.
stylized, simple representations of reality that can lead to important insights.
exact, careful representations of reality.
quite limited in their usefulness.

question.body: Concerning the efficiency versus equity tradeoff:

choice.body: Economists have much to say about both efficiency and equity.
Economists have much more to say about equity than efficiency.
Economists have much to say about efficiency but little to say about equity.
Economists have much to say about equity but nothing to say about efficiency.

question.body: (T/F) Opportunity costs arise only when money is exchanged.

choice.body: True
False

question.body: (T/F) Government can do things to make overall economic fluctuations less severe.

choice.body: True
False

question.body: Which one of the following statements is not an underlying idea of economics?

choice.body: Markets are efficient.
When markets fail, government can provide a solution.
Individuals are always rational and always follow their incentives.
Scarcity is the economic problem.

question.body: Which one of the following does not improve our standard of living?

choice.body: trade
specialization
productivity
market failure

question.body: Considering the top 10 companies' R&D spending, the _____________ industry spends the most.

choice.body: drug
food
electronics
auto

question.body: The Big Three automakers in America have seen their market share fall by _________ from 1960 to 2008.

choice.body: over 50%
40 percentage points
30 percentage points

question.body: A college degree in Italy is worth

choice.body: more than a college degree in the United States.
five times the worth of a college degree in Canada.
two-and-a-half times the worth of a college degree in Australia.
half as much as a college degree in Germany.

question.body: In which country do taxpayers get the highest dollar return from a college degree?

choice.body: United States
Italy
Germany
Australia

question.body: $100 invested in 1998 in fortune 100 companies would be worth in 2009

choice.body: about $100 more than the same initial investment in a broad stock index.
about $100 less than the same initial investment in a broad stock index.
about the same as the same initial investment in a broad stock index.
about $100.

question.body: During the recession of the early 2000s,

choice.body: an investment in a broad stock index fell, while an investment in the Fortune 100 rose.
an investment in a broad stock index rose, while an investment in the Fortune 100 fell.
investments in both a broad stock index and the Fortune 100 fell.
investments in both a broad stock index and the Fortune 100 rose.

question.body: A college degree benefits

choice.body: only the individual receiving the degree.
both the individual receiving the degree as well as the taxpayers.
the taxpayers more than the individual receiving the degree in the U.S.
only the taxpayers.

question.body: If company XYZ is a Fortune 100 company, then one can expect an investment in XYZ

choice.body: to decline over a long period of time.
to grow at a slower rate than an investment in a broad stock index.
to grow at the same rate as an investment in a broad stock index.
to grow at a faster rate than an investment in a broad stock index.

question.body: From the information given in this "By the Numbers," a reason why Toyota is now the leading seller in America is

choice.body: its greater costs of production than America's Big Three automakers.
its greater expenditure on research and development than America's Big Three automakers.
its lack of innovation.
its higher-paid executives.

question.body: A nation's growth depends on

choice.body: investment in research and development only.
investment in education only.
both investment in research and development and in education.
neither investment in research and development nor investment in education.

question.body: (T/F) Microeconomics concentrates on aggregates such as economic growth and inflation.

choice.body: False
True

question.body: When we have two soft drinks on a hot day and turn down the offer of a free third soft drink because we feel this might be too much and leave us waterlogged, we are

choice.body: using information to gain an advantage in the market.
thinking on the margin.
helping alleviate scarcity by leaving something for someone else.
thinking irrationally because it is free.

question.body: The following figure shows 2006 GDP per capita for selected countries, and the country's corresponding years of life expectancy at birth for both men and women. Russia's per capita GDP is roughly what percent of America's?
In following figure, which country has the highest life expectancy for males/females?

choice.body: Japan/Japan
Japan/United Kingdom
United Kingdom/United States
France/Germany

question.body: The following figure shows the median (middle person) duration of unemployment in weeks for each month for 2002–2004. Notice that there is a spike in how long people have been unemployed each June. Which of the following is probably the best explanation for these spikes in how long people have been unemployed?

choice.body: Federal law restricts the number of people who can interview for federal jobs in the summer because of budget limitations.
May and June represent graduation in both high school and college, so the job market becomes crowded and many unemployed individuals can't find work.
The unemployed see the arrival of summer as a chance to surf and do not bother to look for a job.
Employers do not like to hire people in June because they don't want to have to let new people go on vacation.

question.body: The following figure shows the relationship between the size of a video file in megabytes and the download time in minutes. What is the slope of the line?

Assume the line (relationship) in the following figure is for your medium-speed DSL line. Now assume you get a high-speed broadband network connection. How does that affect the line in the following figure?

choice.body: Broadband is so fast that the line will equal the horizontal axis.
The line will rotate upward with a larger slope.
The line will rotate downward with a smaller slope.
No impact.

question.body: (T/F) Ceteris paribus means that economists do economics by creating models.

choice.body: False
True

question.body: Macroeconomics covers all EXCEPT which one of the following?

choice.body: sales of NIKE athletic shoes compared to Reeboks
productivity rates
the unemployment rate
the inflation rate

question.body: Models are:

choice.body: quite limited in their usefulness.
exact, careful representations of reality.
stylized, simple representations of reality that can lead to important insights.
useless because they are too simple.

question.body: Concerning the efficiency versus equity tradeoff:

choice.body: Economists have much to say about equity but nothing to say about efficiency.
Economists have much to say about efficiency but little to say about equity.
Economists have much more to say about equity than efficiency.
Economists have much to say about both efficiency and equity.

question.body: (T/F) Opportunity costs arise only when money is exchanged.

choice.body: False
True

question.body: (T/F) Government can do things to make overall economic fluctuations less severe.

choice.body: False
True

question.body: Which one of the following statements is not an underlying idea of economics?

choice.body: Scarcity is the economic problem.
Individuals are always rational and always follow their incentives.
When markets fail, government can provide a solution.
Markets are efficient.

question.body: Which one of the following does not improve our standard of living?

choice.body: market failure
productivity
specialization
trade

question.body: Does your going to college have anything to do with expanding choices or reducing scarcity?

choice.body: No, opportunity costs do not exist when it comes to going to college.
No, scarcity exists; however, since it is dealing with college no opportunity costs exist.
Yes, scarcity exists; therefore, it is important for the student to examine the trade-offs of obtaining a college degree.
Yes, scarcity does exist but it cannot be reduced.

question.body: You normally stay at home on Wednesday nights and study. However, next Wednesday night the college is having a free concert on the main campus. You have to make a choice. This is an example of:

choice.body: opportunity costs.
incentives.
thinking on the margin.
rational decisions.

question.body: You normally stay at home on Wednesday nights and study. However, next Wednesday night the college is having a free concert on the main campus. What is the opportunity cost of going to the free concert?

choice.body: The opportunity cost is the value of the hours studied, and by extension, possibility of higher grades.
The opportunity cost is what the concert would have cost if the college had not sponsored it.
The opportunity cost is the value of the hours you spend going to the concert plus what the concert would have cost if you’d had to pay for a ticket.
The opportunity cost is the value of the hours you spend going to the concert minus what the concert would have cost if you’d had to pay for a ticket.

question.body: Gregg Easterbrook, in his book The Progress Paradox (New York: Random House, 2003), noted that life in the United States is significantly better today than in the past and provided many statistical facts, including: nearly a quarter of households have incomes of at least $75,000 a year; real (inflation adjusted) per capita income has more than doubled since 1960—people on average have twice the real purchasing power now as in 1960; in 1956, the typical American had to work 16 weeks for each 100 square feet of new housing. Today that number is 14 weeks, and new houses are considerably more luxurious; the United States accepts more legal immigrants than all other nations of the world combined. Even though these facts show that our lives have improved, people feel that life was better in an earlier time. All of the following explain why this is the case except:

choice.body: the media attention focused on the problems.
we romanticize earlier times.
we get used to what we have and wish we had more.
we really don’t care about our standard of living.

question.body: In 2001 Nobel Prize winner Robert Solow noted that “the computer age is seen everywhere except in productivity data.” More recent studies suggest that it takes roughly seven years for investment in computers to have an impact on productivity. All of the following reasons explain why this is the case except:

choice.body: computers require extensive training.
firms must establish the organizational structure to make the investment truly effective.
computers and technology are constantly changing.
the use of technology requires a lot of experience.

question.body: In contrasting equity and efficiency, why do high-tech firms seem to treat their employees better (better wages, benefits, working environments, vacations, etc.) compared to how landscaping or fast-food franchises treat their employees?

choice.body: High-tech firms have to account for the high supply in labor.
Individuals for high-tech firms are in high demand and have a lot of experience.
The turnover rate is too high for fast-food franchises so those employers cannot afford to pay them.
Fast food franchises can pay their employees the same amount as the high-tech firms; they choose not to pay them that amount.

question.body: People talk about a big fall in the housing market. All of the following groups are hurt by this fall except:

choice.body: newly married couples.
real estate agents.
current homeowners.
home builders.....

question.body: In 2006 the Nobel Peace Prize went to economist Muhammad Yunus and the Grameen Bank “for their efforts to create economic and social development from below.” Yunus led the development of micro loans to poor people without financial security: loans of under $200 to people so poor they could not provide collateral, to use for purchasing basic tools or other basic implements of work. This helped to pull millions of people out of poverty. Which of the following statements about how economic prosperity and security for everyone might result in a more peaceful planet is not correct?

choice.body: Economic development means more education.
Micro credit promotes entrepreneurship.
While peace is not associated with prosperity, prosperity in and of itself is a good thing.
Educated and prosperous people are less likely to wage war with their neighbors.

question.body: The Wall Street Journal recently noted that bachelor’s degrees in economics were up 40% between 1999 and 2004: “There is a clear explosion in economics as a major,” and “the number of students majoring in economics has been rising even faster at top colleges.” (Jessica E. Vascellaro, “The Hot Major for Undergrads Is Economics,” Wall Street Journal, July 5, 2005, p. A11.) All of the following are reasons why this is the case except:

choice.body: The starting pay for economic majors upon graduation approaches $50,000 a year.
Globalization trends are producing a greater interest in knowing how economies interact.
Economic analysis is now being applied to a broader range of topics including issues such as crime, AIDS, college and professional sports, and terrorism.
The colleges are no longer offering enticing programs.

question.body: The black rhinoceros is extremely endangered. Its horn is considered a powerful aphrodisiac in many Asian countries, and a single horn fetches many thousands of dollars on the black market, creating a great incentive for poachers. Unlike other stories of endangered species, this one might have a simple solution. Conservationists could simply capture as many rhinos as possible and remove their horns, reducing the incentive to poach. Do you think this will help reduce poaching?

choice.body: Yes, people will begin to see the harm they are doing to these animals.
No, people will still want to participate in this activity.

question.body: With higher gasoline prices, the U.S. government wants people to buy more hybrid cars that use much less gasoline. Unfortunately, hybrids are approximately $4,000 to $5,000 more expensive to purchase than comparable cars. If people follow incentives, the government can do all of the following to encourage the purchase of hybrids except:

choice.body: provide subsidies.
provide tax credits.
provide gas vouchers.
increase taxes on producers of hybrids.

question.body: The By the Numbers box suggests that the stocks of companies that are good to work for (such as Google, Cisco, Genentech, Goldman Sachs, and Adobe) also tend to outperform general stock market averages. All of the following are factors that account for stellar stock market performance except:

choice.body: the businesses charge high prices for their products which increases the profitability of the organization.
employees are loyal to the organization.
employees have high levels of productivity.
the firms have interesting breakthroughs which generate excitement and pride in the organization.

question.body: “If millions of people are desperate to buy and millions more desperate to sell, the trades will happen, whether we like it or not.” This quote by Martin Wolf refers to trades in illicit goods like narcotics, knockoffs (counterfeit goods), slaves, organs, and other goods we generally refer to as “bads.” He suggests that the only way to eliminate traffic in these illicit goods is to eliminate their profitability. Do you agree?

choice.body: No, individuals will always have a demand for these items even if the profitability was low.
Yes, if the profitability is low, people will lose their incentives to sell these things.
No, when cigarettes and alcohol became legal, consumers still had a high demand for those goods and services.
Yes, people will begin to see that these goods are really bad for their health.

question.body: Does your going to college have anything to do with expanding choices or reducing scarcity?

choice.body: No, opportunity costs do not exist when it comes to going to college.
No, scarcity exists; however, since it is dealing with college no opportunity costs exist.
Yes, scarcity exists; therefore, it is important for the student to examine the trade-offs of obtaining a college degree.
Yes, scarcity does exist but it cannot be reduced.

question.body: Gregg Easterbrook, in his book The Progress Paradox (New York: Random House, 2003), noted that life in the United States is significantly better today than in the past and provided many statistical facts, including: nearly a quarter of households have incomes of at least $75,000 a year; real (inflation adjusted) per capita income has more than doubled since 1960—people on average have twice the real purchasing power now as in 1960; in 1956, the typical American had to work 16 weeks for each 100 square feet of new housing. Today that number is 14 weeks, and new houses are considerably more luxurious; the United States accepts more legal immigrants than all other nations of the world combined. Even though these facts show that our lives have improved, people feel that life was better in an earlier time. All of the following explain why this is the case except:

choice.body: the media attention focused on the problems.
we romanticize earlier times.
we get used to what we have and wish we had more.
we really don’t care about our standard of living.

question.body: In 2001 Nobel Prize winner Robert Solow noted that “the computer age is seen everywhere except in productivity data.” More recent studies suggest that it takes roughly seven years for investment in computers to have an impact on productivity. All of the following reasons explain why this is the case except:

data.title: Quiz
data.description:
An assignment primarily designed to assess knowledge. Quizzes replicate the experience of traditional in-class quizzes, in that they are often timed and do not incorporate support opportunities.

Typical Uses
• Reading verification
• Summative Assessment

tr.td: This will be hidden from students by default

{value}

data.title: Agreement with There is and There was
